Posts.Content: Jun 6, 2008 10:27AM Pam_E wrote: I just remembered that for the Taxotere they put my hands and feet in bags of ice.  It's supposed to help prevent the neuropathy in your fingers and toes.  I don't know if it works, but I did it every time with my hands and only the first time with my feet.  I had worse neuropathy in my feet than my hands and the hands cleared up faster.  Both hands and feet are ok now. I agree with Susan that it is hard to ask for and accept help.  This may be the one thing I learned from this whole cancer experience.  People want to help and it's ok to let them help you.  Sometimes I think part of being strong is knowing when you need help.  I am blessed to have the most wonderful neighbors and friends.  I had meals brought to me, people driving me to appointments when I needed a driver and neighbors taking care of my lawn and shoveling snow.  There's no way I could have done it myself.
Posts.Title: Questions for the experienced mrscrj mrscrj

Posts.Content: Jun 5, 2008 04:34PM Pam_E wrote: Carol,  I had 4 AC and 4 Taxotere 2 weeks apart. For the AC I was given a prescription for Emend to take before chemo and for 2 days after.  It prevents nausea and works really well (it's really expensive though).  I always ate before chemo and never got sick.  After your first chemo you'll figure out what works best for you.  Don't eat your favorite meal - if you get sick, you might not ever want it again.  There is no reason for you to get nausea, they have drugs that will prevent it. The day after chemo I was given a shot of Neulasta.  The Neulasta made my bones and muscles sore beginning the day after the shot and lasted for 2-3 days.  I sailed through the AC without any problems, only the pain from the Neulasta.  They cut the Neulasta dose way back because my blood counts would get too high (that's what was causing the pain in my bones).  I got a stomach ache after my first chemo and they put me on Prilosec for the duration of chemo.  The only other thing was the steroids.  I would get very flushed and my vision would be blurry for a couple days. The Taxotere was not much fun, but doable.  My nails became stained and spotted and lifted in places, though I never lost a nail.  I had some neuropathy in my fingers and toes but it has since gone away.  I got very tired with the Taxotere.    My last chemo was Jan. 17th. My fingernails are almost all grown out and look normal again (toenails will take much longer).  My hair started to grow back halfway through the Taxotere and is now about 1 1/4" long.  If any symptoms come up, whether or not you think they're a side effect, be sure to let your ONC know.  They've seen it all and can help you out.  Be gentle with yourself and know that you can get through it. Take care, Pam
Posts.Title: Questions for the experienced mrscrj mrscrj

Posts.Content: Feb 14, 2008 08:40AM Pam_E wrote: Many things either didn't taste right or had no taste at all.  I kept trying different things and found some that worked for me - chocolate, chili, oatmeal, toast.  I did make myself eat nutritious food, but stuck with things that either tasted good or had no taste.  3 weeks after my last chemo (taxotere), my taste buds started to come back.  It's wonderful to have food taste good again, but now I really need to watch my weight.  Everyone's different - you'll just have to keep trying things.
Posts.Title: I Want My Tastebuds Back Bonnielv licorice2006

Posts.Content: Mar 28, 2008 01:49PM Pam_E wrote: I recommend the port.  I had one put in on the same day as my first chemo.  It will save your veins and they can also use it for blood draws.  I always had my blood drawn the same day as chemo tx and they left the gadget in after the blood draw so I only had to be stuck once.  Needle sticks don't bother me, but they can give you some numbing cream to put on first if you want.  Save the veins in your hand and arms!!  I felt that getting it put in and taken out was pretty minor and well worth it.
Posts.Title: Is a port better for chemo or IV in hand??? Lano Texgirl

Posts.Content: Jul 9, 2008 02:18PM Pam_E wrote: I started having pain in my arm (opposite side of mast) a couple months after I finished chemo.  My onc sent me for an MRI and they saw something on the MRI they wanted to check further.  My onc thought it was a bone cyst which you get in your teens and is benign but sent me for a PET scan which came back clear.  It's just carpal tunnel syndrome.  My onc said it is unrelated to bc or chemo but I'm wondering if it has anything to do with the Tamoxifen.  Anyway, I never thought I would be glad to say "it's just carpal tunnel".  There were no painkillers that would touch the pain but I've been wearing a brace most of the time, especially driving and sleeping, and it's made a world of difference.  Very little pain or numbness anymore.  Get it checked out.  It'll help to know exactly what you're dealing with.  Good luck!
Posts.Title: trapped nerve? or something more sinister babybellebooboo babybellebooboo
